CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.
Gathered by our Reporters.

The Government seed grain has commenced to arrive.

George Macdonald arrived back from the east on the last mail.

Miss Stewart, niece of Mr. J. Stewart, left for Medicine Hat yesterday.

The North-West Mounted Police have started for the season's navigation.

The Gold Medal for the Saskatchewan Rifle Association has been received by the Secretary.

Mr. T. Goodfellow has commenced the erection of a large building at the corner of McKay and River streets.

The annual meeting of the Argyle Rock Club was held yesterday evening.

April 2nd, at Garven & Co.'s work shop, at 6 o'clock.

The last of the series of entertainments for the members of the St. Paul's Presbyterian Church Young People's Association will take place on Friday evening, April 1st.

Over three thousand dollars have been subscribed towards building the proposed school at the edge of the townsite.

It will be erected on the square to the east of the present building.

Increased demands for supplies of the Department of Indian Affairs that Indians alone shall be located on reserves, the last of the supplies was yesterday removed to Duck Lake.

The Rev. Dr. Jasmin delivered a powerful address on Sunday night in the Presbyterian church on last Friday evening but, we regret to say, the audience was not so large as former occasions. The lecture was very interesting, and those who were absent missed a lot.

There should be good in Prince Albert this summer, as a large amount of money will be spent in the vicinity.

A severe snow blockade prevails in many portions of eastern Canada.

The sooner the extension of the railway between the United States and the United States are published. Among the difficulties added to the last act, the sale of land for the railway, and the raising of the value of $100,000,000 in bonds. Malicious injuries whereby any person shall be endangered, etc.

Baron Temesky has written a jubilee which is generally ridiculed.

The Colonel defeated the Dauntless in the first round by a unanimous decision.

Alex Macarthur, of Winnipeg, won the Canadian Prize Pole vaulting competition.

Campbell defeated O'Neil in the annual race on the Thames on Monday last.

For opposition against the disbursement of government railway moneys still continues in Manitoba.

The police have disclosed the fact that the teaching from Banquet, but as the latter point is within the province of the C.P.R. charter no importance can be attached to the statement.

The policy will not be permitted to continue being issued against the old Fireboards of Manitoba.

The Manitoba Legislature meets April 15th.

As a result of the recent election, the Liberals were returned, but the precise condition of matters will not be known until the House meets.

Mr. Blake has returned from South Dakota and affords every encouragement to withdraw his resignation.

The Mounted Police authorities are making arrangements for the usual trailing, fill vacant positions by the selection of men who have served a regular period. About one hundred are needed.

A cable to the Globe says: "The Manchester Guardian yesterday published a list of names of persons who were to be named to the Perceval and appointed Governor General of Canada, an successor.

Hon. David Laird is here. He accepted his defeat by the Police vote, which he had thought would be enough to take away his seat.

It is said that the Police voted for the Government with the hope of getting work and medals.

The Saturday last, March 20th, the 2nd detachment of the Duck Lake light infantry, led by Captains Macdonald, Gordon, Arndt, Garrett and Gibson were brought from Canada and landed, side by side, with the 1st detachment of the same regiment, who fell in the same engagement, in St. Mary's church yard. The bodies were afterwards placed in the gallery of Rev. Mr. H. Wright.

It was two years yesterday (May 1st) since the massacre occurred, and of the five white strangers who were killed, Mr. Macdonald is the only survivor, the late Lord Bishop of Saskatchewann and the late Lord Bishop of New Brunswick also.

Two of the twelve killed at Duck Lake are seven living in St. Mary's parish. It is said that the Bishop has been most anxious that some speedy and definite steps are to be taken by the "Monument Committee."

FRIDAY, APRIL 1, 1879.

LOCAL REPRESENTATION.

It will be remembered that at the time the election was held last year in the Northwest Commission Mr. Hughes objected to the way he treated his constituents. He claimed that in taking over from our district such a large number of representatives, it would be impossible for him to adequately represent them all. This latter claim seems to be well founded, for he has been unable to get a fair share of votes from his constituents.

The question, therefore, that seems to arise is, can we not re-arrange the districts so as to give each member a fair share of votes?

Taking Saskatchewan's average per member—40—Assiniboia would be entitled to 16 members.

Taking Assiniboia's average—30—Saskatchewan would be entitled to 14 members.

Taking Alberta's average—25—Saskatchewan would be entitled to 14 members.

TAKING SASKATCHEWAN'S DISTRICT.

New that immigrants are arriving in Winnipeg, and that they will be seeking opportunity to settle, we think it nothing more natural than to distribute the advantages this district offers to those who propose to follow the present system of settlement.

The one great drawback to the settlement here, in the past, has been the fact that we were further away from the centre of population in the east than any other part. The result has been that our prospect for settlement have not yet been realized.

The further back we go into the wilderness within this district it naturally draws us towards the east instead of settling anywhere else.

This has been the case ever since the opening of the C.P.R., or were preceeded from distance alone, but now with the advance of two railways towards the borderlands to this district, and the town of Prince Albert will have excellent communication with the east.

But still the fact that a railway passes through our district is of great importance, as it enables us to be nearer to the east than any other part. We are also better situated for settlement then any other part, and our position on the North Saskatchewan river will enable us to take advantage of the navigable waterway along this river.

We will now turn our attention to the capital of the new Province of Saskatchewan, and will apply all the advances which these new communications will bring with them.

But there is another important consideration which we must take into account before establishing this district entirely independent from the others.

The question, therefore, that arises is, can we not make a fair adjustment of the districts so as to give each member a fair share of votes?

Analyzing the Baking Powders.

Under the direction of the New York State Board of Health, eighty-four samples of baking powders, containing all the brands that could be found in the market, were subjected to examination and analysis by Prof. C. F. Chamberlain, a member of the State Board of Health, assisted by Prof. Edward G. Lowe, the well-known United States chemist.

The official report shows that a large number of the powders examined were found to contain alum or lime, many of them being so strongly charged as to be seriously objectionable for use in the preparation of human food.

Alum was found to be a very nice sam- pling drug employed in baking powders to sharpen their cost. The presence of the same was attributed to the addition of tartar in small quantities to their manufacture. Such cream of tartar was also analyzed, and found to be adulterated with alum to the extent of 35 per cent. of their entire weight.

All the powders passed the test of the presence of tartar in their manufacture. The cost of this chemically pure cream of tartar is greatly reduced, and the effect of the account of this greater cost is used in making baking powder but the "Royal."

AGRICULTURAL.

Flax Culture.

In reply to a question from "H.R.", Prince Albert, asking for information about the culture of flax, the "New West Farmer" says:—The first thing to ensure success in growing flax is to choose the right variety and if so, to what advantage. It has been successfully grown here in Ontario, but Major Smith at Lindsay claims he could produce a tall different variety. A slight summer frost would spoil a season crop, and anything for cattle a paltry sum to be obtained for seed. If it is not as profitable as some people allege. I own as, when it is in its new breaking stage, it will make a good fence. It is also said to soil from rotting properly, and so spoil the land for several crops afterward. He can say that he has had a crop worth early in June or late in May, and find how it prospered on that scale. He may wish to try it again, but he will have to retire for another year and let us know in November what success he has achieved.

The weather is now getting warmer, and the crops can begin to grow. Why the seed should not be put in before the last of May or early in June, when other crops are just beginning to show their heads? If summer frost affect the crop, and it only takes fourteen weeks to mature, then the loss will be great. Flax is the least likely, in this district, to be spoiled. Besides, if flax will thrive as far north as the Red River Colony (N.W.T.), why not in the Canadian North-West. But, admitting that flax will thrive as far north as the Red River Colony, the question arises whether it would pay to grow it there. The answer is, it has, however, been made a reliable and profitable crop in Ontario and it will also raise in advantageously in Manitoba. Why not in the Saskatchewan country? Of course, the main consideration is the market. England and Ireland are the chief markets for flax. Last year Great Britain used over 100,000 tons of flax, of which nearly 85,000 tons were imported from France. Besides, she bought flax and tow, or cordage, to the value of $26,417,963, and paid out altogether $3,000,000 for raw material in flax. The manufacture of linseed oil has also been commenced in Winnipeg, and the value of the oil exported to the value of $23,127 was exported, besides the quantity used for local consumption. The value of the amount $15,216 went to England. Flax is valued at from $200 to $70 per ton according to the quality. Taking into account the production of European countries as a criterion 8 acres will raise a ton of decent flax, which would give an average return much better than any in this country. With the opening of the Hudson's Bay Company, we do not see why there is no prospect of advantage from supplying the flax mills of Great Britain with all the raw material they require. We have now climbed the ladder of water, and scouting machines of the best quality are always obtainable. In view of the advantages which would accrue, it would be well for the farmers to try a small area of flax this year, and satisfy themselves by practical test as to whether flax will pay them. Our opinion, however, is that it will.

Prime Essay on Butter Making.

From the "New West Farmer."

The following essay on prime butter making won the prize of $10 at the Wisconsin dairyman's convention, Richland Center. The essay was written by Mr. W. H. Nash, of this city.

To make good butter, all having care of cows and milk should work intelligently, conscientiously and harmoniously, each doing his part to make his best—very best—and do it every day.

Then having good butter cows, they may adopt the following plan with success:

1. Keep cows in clean, warm, ventilated stables in winter.

2. Treat gently, feed water and milk regularly.

3. Feed in winter: corn, oats, ground, mix with bran, meal and salt occasionally; also carrots, parsnips, turnips, celery, clover and straw stalks. Avoid turnips, cabbage and decaying vegetables.

4. Feed in summer: good pasture and feeding troughs.

5. Pure water at all seasons.

6. Scrupulous cleaning of all utensils. [We add here freedom from stable odor, cleanliness of all ill-ventilated cellars.—Ed. N.W.F.]

7. Milk rapidly and quietly in a pail that strains while milking, or cover pan with folds of mosquito netting; re strain through both wire and cloth into deep case.

8. Reduce and hold temperature at 50 degrees.

9. Skin sweet.

10. Keep cream at moderate temperature until thickened, which indicates proper curdling.

11. Air by frequent stirring.

12. Churn in summer in early morning every other day, Sundays excepted. In winter not less than once weekly. Temperature 60 degrees.

13. Stop churning when in granular state, draw buttermilk and sell. Add twice, in pure, white cream, thin with brine, then remove butter to pan. Gather cream, drain, repeat operation on traces of buttermilk.

14. Butter still in granules, salt (pure dairy 1 oz. per lb.), by stirring evenly, effervesce, then pack.

15. Pack immediately in boxes, previously filled with hot brine, then thoroughly cooled.

16. Cover neatly with muslin and set in cool, dry place to await shipment.

Miscellaneous.

Farmers, do not forget to give your stock milk if you want them to improve. Working ox or milch cow, 2 ounces; fattening stall cows, 2½ to 4 ounces; fattening pigs, 4 to 6 ounces; young pigs, 6 to 8 ounces; calves, 4.

Deep ploughing should be confined to rich lands, and the ploughing should be done in the fall, while shallow ploughing is the best for thin soil, and should be done in spring, leaving the middle course for moulding.

Ship your grain to market by way of the fur dog or steer. A good strong, fatteering animal can carry 1000 lbs. corn to market at a very reasonable rate.

Cleanliness is absolutely necessary for the health of young fowls. Keep poultry houses clean and airy; it will make a great difference in your sales, as purchasers will not buy where everything is dirty and unhealthy.

In stock raising, as in any other business, the best manager is he who reaps the largest return from a given outlay. Certain rules of business and farming principles must be kept in view, viz., comfort, economy, and profit. The man who does not know enough to make a profit will make a loss. He cannot make a profit from it, and this applies to all stock, from the noblest horse to the humblest cow, and all are needed, and when exercised well repaid.

WHICH UP TO OR DOWN.

On Wednesday, 2nd inst., before A. H. Griesbach, J. F. D. Macrae, chargé d'affaires, and Mr. J. M. Macrae, chargé d' affaires, the following cases came on for hearing:—Mr. J. F. D. Macrae, charged with having sold illicit whiskey, pleaded guilty, and was fined $100 and costs or three months hard labour.

On Friday, before the same J. F. D. Macrae, charged with having sold intoxicating liquor in his possession, pleaded guilty and was fined $100 and costs or two months hard labour.

On the same day Thomas George Crow, charged with having had intoxicating liquor in his possession, pleaded guilty and was fined $100 and costs or three months hard labour.

BATTLEFORD.

From the Herald of March 12th.

Big Bear and his band arrived per freight train today Tuesday, and went into camp in retirement in South Battleford.

The Dominion Rifle Association shield total for 1876 has been returned by the secretary of the Battleford Rifle Association.

Joseph H. Price, farming instructor to the Cree at Eagle Hills, is making a tour of the reserves for the purpose of vaccinating the Indians.

Spring trout fishing is opening lively. Lee is looking busy, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Prince and Mr. Alphonse Belleau, next Monday's stage will bring back Messrs. C. H. Williams, Fred. Margolies, Goodwin Marchand, and T. E. Mahaffy and bring in Sept. Gagnon and Mr. Staley.

The assessment of the Roman Catholic school district of St. Vital (Battlefield) amounts to $30,000, on which the rate fixed is six cents.

The only outward bound passenger on the mail on Wednesday was ex-Captain Miller, who has left for the Old Country after having spent five years in the Mounted Police.

Old-timers are discovering the charms of a bicycle ride, and appreciate the great depth of snow all over the country, especially in the east, and the absence of any snow to thaw up to date.

A bill has been introduced in the lower house of parliament with the low state of water and heavy ice on the Saskatchewan, rendering highly dangerous the river traffic, and will be followed for an unusual extent. But like political prophecies these speculations may all come to nothing.
